Old men preferred as councillors.
Wisdom from god as old (one-eyed) man. Linked to Iceland
Wisdom from old man: always say, "if it pleases God." In languages spoken in Spanish
The cheater cheated.
A rule must work both ways.
Make-believe eating, make-believe work. At table the peasant says, "We will only act as if we were eating." At work the servant replies, "We will only act as if we were working."

Counterfeit money burned up. A priest who has lent money to a Jew, but will not lend to a farmer, on being reproached by the latter, says that the money he lent the Jew was "false". When the Jew gets to know of this, he claims that as soon as he heard the money was false he burnt it up. Linked to Lithuania
Boy pretends to speak only Latin. Father, chastising his lazy son, also speaks in "Latin". Linked to Lithuania, Linked to Russia

The man in place of a watch-dog. The master orders his serf to watch the manor at night in place of the dog. When the thieves come, the serf barks: "Dress, dress .... They take, take .... They lead, lead .... " The master does not understand the barking and pays no heed to it   is robbed of his property. Linked to Lithuania

Oisin's poor diet in Patrick's house pancake size of ivy leaf, measure of butter only size of rowan berry. Later Oisin gives Patrick quarter of a wild boar, servant ivy leaf and rowan berry. Linked to Ireland

Things on highway belong to the public. Man reproves another for picking his cherries that overhang the highway. He is told that things on the public highway belong to no one in particular. He invites the man to climb the tree for better cherries, drives off with his horse and buggy, giving the same answer about things in the public highway. Linked to United States

Can drink only one kind of wine at a time. Priests come to an inn where host gives them good wine and bad. They insist on having all good since they must drink only one kind of wine. On their return he serves them with all bad. They claim to have had the rule changed.
"Eat spiritual food, not material,"  say monks to lazy brother who criticizes them for working in the garden. In languages spoken in Spanish, Linked to Spanish Exempla

Ox bought; buyer also claims load of wood attached. Later deceived man disguises and sells sharper another ox for "handful of coppers." He is allowed by court to claim the hand as well. Linked to India
Priests say dying woman's unfulfilled request for mangoes must be paid in golden mangoes to them. Priests burned with iron since she had asked to be cauterized. Linked to India

Wife surrendered to king. Vizier advises doctor to give up his wife to love-sick prince since everything belongs to a sovereign. Doctor then tells him prince is in love not with his (the doctor's) wife but with the vizier's. India: Thompson-Balys.
Turnips called bacon: cat called rabbit. A peasant compels his servant to call turnips bacon. Under favorable circumstances the servant compels the master to call a cat a rabbit.

Man bathing rich man uses sand instead of sandalwood: "Consider the sand of the Ganges to be sandalwood.". When man asks for his fee, other takes a frog and gives it to him: "Know that the frog of the Ganges is a cow." Linked to India
Goldsmith sells thinly plated gold; peasant retaliates: a pot of dirt with a little gyav on top. Linked to India
Eating cure becomes epidemic. A woman feigns periodic attacks of a sickness that can be cured only by eating a great number of delicacies. The husband feigns the same disease.
Fits become epidemic. After dinner a servant feigns a fit and goes to sleep. The master thereupon feigns a fit and beats the boy, who is thus cured of his laziness. Linked to Russia

The wine-spilling host rebuked. A host spills his customer's wine so that he must buy more. He consoles the guest with "It is a sign of the great abundance you shall have this year." With the same remark the guest draws the spigot from the host's wine cask.

The porter's revenge for the three wise counsels. A man offers a porter three wise counsels for carrying his goods. "When anyone tells you that hunger and satisfaction are the same, don't believe him." The second and third are similar and equally valueless. The porter throws down the load: "When anyone tells you that any part of this load is not broken, don't believe him."

No clothes needed for Day of Judgment. Friends tell a man that the next day is the Day of Judgment and urge him to kill a lamb and give a feast. He apparently consents. He then burns up their clothes. They will not need clothes on the Day of Judgment.

Forbidden to think. A husband forbids a wife to think. During his absence she roasts a chicken, eats it, and leaves two drumsticks on the table. The husband asks for the chicken. "Since you have forbidden me to think, I did not think of you." The ban is lifted.
Master says that he has eyes in back of head: servant cheats him. Holds up food to master's back and then not having objection raised, eats it. Linked to India
Impossible demand rebuked. Linked to Ireland

Milk from the hornless cow. A king demands a hundred men's drink from the milk of a hornless dun cow from every house in the land. Wooden cows are made and bog-stuff substituted for milk; the king must drink it. Linked to Ireland
To return the eye to the one-eyed man. "Let me have your other so that I can see whether the one I bring you matches." Linked to India
Healed with his own medicine.
"If he does not live, let him die.". The student as healer hangs this sign around the neck of a sick calf. Later as parson he is sick. It is proposed to heal him with the same remedy.
You lead and I will follow: hard command thus evaded.
The father of an illegitimate child must walk in front of the cross. Condemned man insists that the priest, who is guilty also, shall lead the way.
Rogues exchange objects and cheat each other. Linked to India
Thieves deceived by prearranged conversation which they overhear.
Overheard conversation: "Mustard has advanced in price.". Thieves steal mustard and leave all else. Linked to India
Overheard conversation: "Money hidden in wall (field).". Thieves take box filled with stone (or dig up field). Linked to India
Overheard conversation: "My money is hanging in the tree.". Thieves stung by hornets. Linked to India
Wisdom (knowledge) from sage (teacher). In languages spoken in Spanish, Linked to Spanish Exempla, Referenced in Jewish religious texts, Linked to Ireland
Cynical philosopher lives in tub. Linked to Spanish Exempla, In languages spoken in Spanish
Advice from dervish.
Philosopher instructs youth regarding conduct. Linked to Italy
Philosopher consoles woman for loss of son. Linked to Italy
Wisdom from philosopher: give separate greetings to infants, youths, and old people. In languages spoken in Spanish
Wisdom from philosopher: worldly honor like shadow. If one goes toward it, it flees; if one turns his back on it, it follows and at times catches up with one. In languages spoken in Spanish
Swindler's plans foiled.

The shoes carried into the tree. Tricksters induce a numskull to climb a tree, planning to steal his shoes. He takes them in his belt with him. "Perhaps I shall find a nearer road home up there and shall need my shoes."

The old man nods "Yes". A monk at an old man's deathbed asks if he hasn't promised this and that to the church. The old man from weakness rather than understanding nods "Yes". The son standing by asks, "Shall I throw this fellow down stairs?" The old man nods "Yes".
Clever wife of king's adopted son keeps king distracted on deathbed so that he cannot disinherit husband. Linked to India

Command would become permanent. A ruler receives gifts from his subjects and later demands them as he due. The fool sets the nobleman's bed on fire. When the nobleman commands him to put the fire out he refuses, since he would ever afterward have to be putting out fires.

Unjust oath countered by another. A woman entrusts three coins to a headsman. He denies her claim which she fails to substantiate in ordeal. She now claims more and happens to succeed with ordeal. Linked to India
Catching by words.
Bargain: to render service for "something". Claimant has called dead cricket "something" and must be content. Linked to India
Rebuke to the stingy.
Half price for half a shave. A man asks to be shaved at half price. The barber shaves one side. He must pay the other half for the rest of the shave.
Stingy man rebuked when his children are feasted in his absence. They think he has been responsible and honor him. He reforms. Linked to India
Poor girl outwits prince in fright-contest. He frightens her and later mocks her with her words of fright. She plays the same trick on him. Linked to Italy
Soldier's practical retort to officer.

Officer disarmed by sentry. Army major approaches sentry, takes away his rifle, and reproaches him for allowing himself to be disarmed. Sentry draws pistol from inside shirt, demands return of unloaded rifle. Linked to United States
Dream answered by dream. Priests misinterpret raja's dream and get his horses. Trickster advises raja to announce dream demanding cauterization of the priests. They return horses. Linked to India
Wisdom from holy man. Linked to Spanish Exempla, In languages spoken in Spanish, Linked to India
Holy man's prayer reforms rich man. Holy man prays, "May God bless everything here that is good but cause to disappear all that is bad." Everything disappears. Linked to India
Hermit explains why anger is sin.
One absurdity rebukes another. Linked to India
Borrower's absurdities. Linked to United States

The transformed golden pumpkin. Borrower of golden pumpkin returns a brass pumpkin and claims that the gold has turned to brass. The lender takes the borrower's son and returns with an ape. He claims that the boy has turned into an ape. Linked to India
Mill has given birth to horse. Jackal as judge comes late. "Tank of water caught fire." Linked to India

The iron-eating mice. Trustee claims that mice have eaten the iron scales confided to him. The host abducts the trustee's son and says that a falcon has carried him off. Linked to Italy, In languages spoken in Spanish, Linked to India, Linked to Indonesia, Linked to Spanish Exempla

The dog-eating bugs. Man keeps dog for boy, tells him when he comes for it that the chinch bugs have eaten it. The boy borrows a mule from the man, later tells him that a buzzard has carried it away. He gets his dog back. Linked to United States

The pot has a child and dies. A borrower returns a pot along with a small one saying that the pot has had a young one. The pots are accepted. He borrows the pot a second time and keeps it. He sends word that the pot has died. Linked to Romania, Linked to India
Adulteress's absurdity rebuked.

The Snow-Child. (Modus Leibinc.) A sailor's wife bears a son in his absence and says that it came from eating snow. Later the husband makes away with the boy who, he says, melted in the sun. Linked to Italy
Absurdities concerning birth of animals, or men. Linked to India
Deer captured in bird-net: water flows upstream. One partner claims a deer he has captured in his bird-net. The other pretends to be watching water flow upstream.
Ruler's absurdity rebuked.
Absurdity of entrusting military mission to bishop. Courtier rebukes king by asking that he be given an ecclesiastical post. Linked to Italy
Absurdity of trying to convert king to Hinduism like making cow of donkey or black dog into white. Linked to India
One absurdity rebukes another miscellaneous.
Priest forbidden to have female servant ostentatiously washes his own clothes. Bishop reverses the order.

Scholar given third egg. A scholar, showing his skill in logic, proves that two chickens (or eggs) on the table are really three. His father (or host) takes one chicken for himself, gives the other to the mother, tells son that he can have the third one. Found in England

Wise words of dying father. Counsel proved wise by experience. Linked to India, Referenced in Jewish religious texts, Referenced in Jewish religious texts, Linked to Ireland, Linked to Ireland, Linked to Indonesia, Linked to Indonesia, Linked to India, Linked to Iceland, Linked to Iceland
Wise words of father. Linked to Ireland
Dying saint leaves wise message to followers. Message is cryptic, but is finally made clear. Linked to Spanish Exempla, In languages spoken in Spanish
Retorts between husband and wife. Linked to Ireland
Husband outwits his wife.
The good words. A man pledged to give his wife only good words hits her with a prayer book.
Sharing joy and sorrow. Man pledged to do so with his wife follows instructions literally. Beats her a joy to him and a sorrow to her.
The flute makes more noise. A man overcomes his quarrelsome wife by playing the flute as long as she is scolding. Linked to Italy
Woman repulses ugly husband's advances. He placates her by telling her that he wants a handsome child. Linked to Italy
Husband and wife separate and divide property. Man keeps the house, gives the wife the road. Linked to United States
Wife outwits her husband.

Will work when beaten. A wife whose husband has beaten her sends a rumor to the sick king that her husband is a skilled physician but will practice only when he is well beaten. He is seized and whipped.

Four men's mistress. A husband disguises as a priest to hear his wife's confession. She says that she has been mistress of a servant, a knight, a fool, and a priest; i.e., her husband when he was her servant, and later her knight. He had then been a fool for demanding her confession, and was a priest because he had heard it. Linked to Italy

Fault-finding husband nonplussed. The wife has cooked so many dishes that when he complains, she can always supply another. Finally he says, "I had rather eat dung." She produces some. Found in India (Kashmir)
Which does the more work. Wife shows that she does many more tasks in one morning than the husband. Linked to India
Where are the shoes?. Fault-finding husband threatens to hit wife with shoes. She: "You will have to have some shoes first." Linked to India
Man who continually threatens to leave wife mortified when she tells him to go;  pretends his buffalo is dragging him home (after he does leave). Linked to India

The exiled wife's dearest possession. A wife driven from home is allowed by her husband to take her one dearest possession. She takes her sleeping husband and effects reconciliation. Linked to Japan, Referenced in Jewish religious texts
The besieged women's dearest possession. (Women of Weinsberg.) Permitted to carry from the city their dearest possession, they take their husbands.
Husband tells wife in indecent posture to "lock up shop". She retorts that he has the key. Linked to Italy
Wife by cleverness wins back fortune overbearing husband has foolishly lost and humbles him. Linked to India
Clever laughter and response of wife stops husband from fondling maid.

Corpse to be cut in two for easy carrying. Husband who feigns death hears wife propose this. He upbraids her; she replies: "If you had really died I should have given myself up to be burnt." Linked to India
Wife shows deep water. Husband declares that he will drown himself. The wife shows him a deep spot in the stream. Found in England

Overcurious wife learns of the senate's deliberations. Husband (son) tells her that they have decided that each man may have many wives. Gullible wife believes it. In languages spoken in Spanish, Linked to Italy, Linked to Spanish Exempla
Wisdom (knowledge) from women. Linked to Spanish Exempla, In languages spoken in Spanish, Linked to Iceland
Hero directed on journey by princess. Linked to Iceland
Serpent directed on journey by his beautiful wife. Linked to India
King has amours with great men's wives so as to learn secrets from them.
Caesar's scorn of his wife's advice leads to disaster.
Wife as adviser. Linked to India
Wife of usurer saves husband through her prayers.
Wise words of dying woman (queen). Linked to Iceland
Knowledge from mysterious women met in the forest. Linked to Iceland
Wisdom from harlot to a king. Linked to India
Practical retorts: borrowers and lenders.
Imaginary debt and payment. Referenced in Hindu religious texts
Imagined intercourse, imagined payment. A woman demands money for a visit which she dreams of having had from a merchant. She is shown the money in a mirror. Linked to India

The priest administers to a man sick with infectious disease. Shows him the Host through window, and says: "Have hope and imagine you receive it." The man shows the priest a coin through the window, and repeats the same phrase. Linked to Lithuania
"Here is half of picture and you must imagine other half.". Jester later redecorates house in fragments of pictures. Linked to India

Imagined penance for imagined sin. A penitent confesses that a plan to sin had entered his mind. Priest tells him that the thought is as good as the deed. Assesses four florins as penance. Penitent says that he had only had it in his mind to give the florins; he must take the thought for the deed.
Singer repaid with promise of reward: words for words. Referenced in Hindu religious texts
Directions for getting pay given in return for directions for healing.

Substitute for candle repaid with substitute for money. A monk gives a man a stick instead of the candle the man has wanted to burn before a holy picture. The monk says that it will have the same effect as if the candle were burned. The man takes out his purse and lets the monk touch it.

The hare at third remove. A man receives a present of a hare. Later a crowd comes to him for entertainment saying that they are friends of the man who presented the hare. This happens a second time. He serves them clear water. "It is the soup from the soup of the hare."
Imagined ownership: derived from a dream. Man claims ownership of bulls because he has dreamed of them. He is given their shadows. Linked to Italy

Imagined color. Clerk tells person to imagine that blue cloth is green. The customer walks out without paying. The clerk asks for payment; the customer tells clerk to imagine he has been paid. Linked to United States
Half of money thrown into tank. The monkey to the grocer: "You sold half water and half milk." Linked to India
Loans refused.
The ass consulted about the loan. A man wants to borrow an ass. The owner goes to see what the ass says. The ass is unwilling.
The ass is not at home. A man wants to borrow an ass. The owner says that the ass is not at home. The ass brays and the borrower protests. "Will you believe an ass and not a graybeard like me?"

The bigger fool. When told by servants their master is not at home, man says it is a fool that goes out in such midday heat. Whereupon master sticks his head out of the window, saying "Thou who art moving about at this time art the big fool: I have been seated all day in my house." Linked to India

Three reasons for refusing credit. A man asks for credit, although he has always paid cash before. He is refused on these grounds: either (1) he has never found anyone to trust him, (2) he has never bought anything, or (3) he is rich and does not need an extension of time.

Man refuses to lend horse: sued for consequent damages. The would-be borrower gets one from another neighbor. He overworks the horse and renders him useless. The owner of the horse sues the man who had refused to lend his animal. Reasoning: "If he had lent his horse this would not have happened to mine." Settled by compromise. Linked to Italy

Better to donate half of what is asked than lend all. Two farmers ask a priest to lend two measures of grain to each of them. The priest refuses to lend them any but donates one measure to each. Thus he saves two measures. Linked to Italy
Lender repays borrower for deceptive loan.
Borrower of butter receives pot of cowdung with little butter on top:  repays by lending wooden sword covered with thin iron. Linked to India
Miscellaneous retorts concerning borrowing and lending.

A present or a retaining fee. An abbot presents a lawyer with a fine horse. Later the abbot comes to Rome and calls on the lawyer for help. The latter returns the horse. "I did not know that you had a lawsuit in Rome."

God as surety; the abbot pays. A young man is ransomed by giving God as surety for the ransom money. He fails to return as agreed. The creditor sees a wealthy abbot, who says that he is a servant of God. He robs the abbot and when the young man finally appears he tells the latter than the debt is already paid by God's servant.
Too large a payment. A student leaving the university sends back a small coin to pay for the knowledge he is carrying away, although he says that he is really paying too much.
Wisdom from fools. Linked to Ireland
Wisdom from fool: make peace before rather than after the war.
Wisdom from fool: absurdity of tight-rope walker's performance.

Wisdom from fool: the present returned. Nobleman gives fool a present; he is to give it to no one who is not a greater fool. Master is dying; doctor tells fool that master is going to take long journey. Since master is making no preparation, fool gives him the present. Master thus brought to repentance.
Wisdom from fool: heaven refused. Fool says he does not want to go to heaven for he wants to stay with his master, who everyone says is going to hell. Master repents.
Practical retorts: hosts and guests.
Inhospitality repaid. Linked to Ireland, Linked to India
Clothes thrown into the cooking food. A trickster when told that food cooking is clothes being boiled retaliates by throwing his dirty hose into the pot.

Inhospitable host punished for hospitality. An abbot has his innkeeper treat his guests with the most shameful neglect. A guest retaliates by telling the abbot that he has been very sumptuously entertained. The innkeeper is discharged.

Welcome to the clothes. A man at a banquet is neglected because of his poor clothes. He changes clothes, returns, and is honored. "Feed my clothes," he says, "for it is they that are welcomed." Linked to Italy, Linked to India
Poor suitor served good supper prepared for rich one. Recites a satirical rhymed grace. Found in North Carolina
Servant repays stingy master (mistress). Linked to India
Hostess says that she has no spoons. Otherwise she would be glad to give something to eat. A joker brings along the necessary spoons.
The boy "loses his sight.". No butter on the bread.
Father causes inhospitable daughter to spoil her feast by deceptive advice about cooking. Linked to India

A box connection. Man refused hospitality tells rich man he is a relative. Asked for the "connection," he tells him there is a box connection. Rich man not understanding, man explains his cart is made of box wood and is tied to a rich man's box tree. Rich man, ashamed, entertains him with all due respect. Linked to India
Grace said in name of the host. Neglected guest thus gets his portion of food. Referenced in Jewish religious texts
The greedy host.

Turning the plate around. A cuts the meat and puts all the good things on his side. B turns the plate around: "See how all things turn about in this world." A turns it back: "However the world may turn, with good friends like us the plate will always remain the same." Linked to Lithuania, Linked to Estonia

The peasant's share is the chicken. He serves small birds and a roast chicken to his guests. Guests each take a small bird, leaving only the chicken when the plate reaches the host. He takes the whole chicken saying: "Since everyone has a bird, I must have one too."
Host hides meat in his clothing. It attracts his dog and he is exposed. Linked to Italy
Treatment of difficult guests.
The guest who could not keep warm. He keeps calling for more bed clothes. The host finally piles a ladder, a trough, etc., on top of him until he calls for help.
Guests make impossible demands of host: host's representative forces guests to leave by sending them on difficult quest. Linked to Ireland
Bread baked with onions for an undesirable guest. Linked to India
Proper food for ox and ass. Guests call each other ox and ass. Host offers green grass for the first and fodder for the second. Linked to India
Guests frightened away by housewife. Linked to India

Wife prepares the pestle. Tells guests husband uses it against guests. They flee. Tells husband they left because she refused to give them pestle. Husband pursues to give them the pestle, but they run the faster. Linked to India
Servants touch cooking pot. Food being considered unclean then, guests depart empty but unwitting of true reason. Linked to India
When hints do not get rid of unwelcome guests, force must be used. Thus man treats his sons-in-law. Linked to India
A sham fight to frighten away the guests. Linked to India
Priest frightens away parasitic guests. Tells them he has that morning confessed man with plague. Linked to France
Talker keeps person from eating.

Trickster's interrupted feast revenged. He is asked a question by his master each time he tries to eat a date, so that he always has to spit out the date. He revenges himself that night when the master tries to carry on an intrigue with his wife's maid. He comes with his answers at embarrassing moments.

Revenge by interrupting feast. A rabbi who has been inhospitably treated is afterwards invited to dinner. He keeps the guests so amused by his jokes that they fail to eat and the feast is spoiled. Referenced in Jewish religious texts
Inappropriate entertainment repaid. Linked to Ireland
Fox and crane invite each other. Fox serves the food on a flat dish so that the crane cannot eat. Crane serves his food in a bottle. Associated with the tribe Africa (Mpongwe)
Bugs unable to eat honey at banquet of bees, and bees unable to eat dung at bug's dinner. In languages spoken in Spanish, Linked to Spanish Exempla
Crop division between parrot and cat: they try to cheat each other by inviting to a dinner in turns every day. Linked to India
Luxury of host rebuked.
Philosopher spits in king's beard. It is the only place he can find at the royal table not covered with gold and jewels. Linked to Italy, Linked to Spanish Exempla, In languages spoken in Spanish
Ruler refuses hospitality from subject who spends more than he earns. Linked to Italy
Wisdom (knowledge) from dream. Linked to Iceland, Linked to India, Referenced in Jewish religious texts
Deity appears in dream and gives instructions or advice. Linked to India
Wisdom from dream: the leper with the cup of water. Man in dream willing to receive sacrament from unworthy priest.
Fate of parents revealed in dream. Mother shown in Hell; father in Heaven. Linked to Italy
Dream advises against the popularizing of science. Linked to Italy
Host rebukes negligent servant.
A step-ladder for setting the table. Servant who leaves off the salt is instructed to bring in the step-ladder so as to see what is missing.
Guest brings along cakes to eat. Stingy host rebuked. Linked to Italy, In languages spoken in Spanish

Suitor brings own lamp. Mother of girl tells suitor that she cannot have him burning her midnight oil. The next night he brings his own lamp and a can of oil, tells her he will stay all night if he wishes. Linked to United States
"Cause liberality to be depicted.". Answer of hungry man when host asks for suggestion for a picture to be painted of something that has not been seen. Linked to Italy
Deceptive invitation to feast.
Inviting to a feast only those whose households have never been touched by death. None comes. Linked to India
Wisdom from angel. Referenced in Jewish religious texts
Solomon pays heed to angel's warning. Rules wisely. Linked to Italy
Practical retorts connected with almsgiving.
Stingy almsgiving repaid.

Poem for poem: all for all. A poet gives the emperor a poem, hoping for a reward The emperor later gives the poet a poem in return. The poet thereupon sends the emperor two pennies, saying that this is all the money he has. The emperor, seeing that he is defeated in the exchange, laughs and becomes the poet's friend.

Reinforcement of the request for alms. A clown asks for alms and receives nothing. He then throws pellets made of herbs at the steward, saying that there is great power in words, herbs, and stones: he has tried two of them and plans to try the third. He is given alms.
Base money in the offering.

The penny baked in the wafer. A peasant always puts a bad penny into the offering. The priest has a penny baked in a wafer and gives it to the peasant at communion. The peasant, unable to swallow it, thinks that he is possessed of the devil. The priest asks whether he has ever done wrong with a penny, secures confession and a pledge of reform.
Sulphur in the censer. Parishioners put base money into the collection. The priest burns sulphur instead of incense He tells them that their money will buy nothing better.
Interested only in his capital. Preacher tells parishioners (regarding the day's offering): "You will get back 100 for 1." Donor of a penny: "I'll be glad to get back my capital!" Linked to Italy
Any boon desired. Stingy king insists on trickster asking any boon desired. By asking king to perform disgusting act, trickster compels king to give expensive gift. Linked to India
Dove disregards experience and loses brood. Rebuilds her nest in the place where she has lost former brood. In languages spoken in Spanish, Linked to Spanish Exempla
Practical retorts miscellaneous.
How much the ass cost. As the fool brings the new ass home everyone wants to know how much it cost. He has all publicly assemble and announces just what it cost. In languages spoken in Spanish

Throw at a rich man. Philosopher gives a penny to a man who throws stones at him but advises him that it will be wiser to throw at one who can afford to give more. The advice is followed and the rascal is arrested and hanged.
Eyes treated for the stomach ache. A man who has stomach ache from eating bad bread is treated for his eyes so that he will thereafter be able to tell good bread from bad. Linked to India

The fish in the sleeve. A particularly obnoxious man delays others while he haggles over prices with a butcher. Meanwhile a parson takes the three fish the man has laid down and puts them into his large sleeves. The man is angry and searches in vain for them. The parson then shows them and advises him not to let people cheat him.

One wrong and five hundred good deeds. A man steals a large sum, keeps half and distributes the rest among five hundred persons. He says that he has committed one wrong but has done five hundred good deeds.

Two monks renew their appetites. Entertained by a lord, they say that they are going to certain waters to recover their appetites. They are taken to a chamber and locked in for a day They recover their appetites without further journeying.
Hungry man eats intestines of fish next morning after refusing to do so the evening before. Linked to India
The testament of the dog. The owner of a dog has him given Christian burial. The bishop thereupon pretends that the dog has left the church a large legacy. Linked to Italy

Ass's charter in his hoof. The ass absents himself from the parliament of beasts. The lion sends the fox and the wolf to summon him. He pleads his charter of exemption and invites the fox to read it in his hoof. Linked to Italy
Trial rehearsed before stick in the ground as judge.
The stolen meat and the weighed cat. A man buys three pounds of meat. His wife eats it and says that the cat ate it. The man weighs the cat and finds that it does not weigh three pounds.

The lazy ass repaid in kind. Loaded with salt, he falls down in the river and lightens his burden. His master then loads him with sponges so that the next time the ass tries the trick he increases his load.
The rescuers' Sabbath. A Jew, fallen into a pit, refuses to be rescued on Saturday, his Sabbath. The next day he calls for help but the Christians refuse to rescue him on Sunday, their Sabbath.

The forehanded servant. A parson boasts that when he asks his maid if certain work is done she always answers that it has been done long ago. A guest wagers that she can be trapped if she is asked whether she has thrown the parson's suit of clothes into the tub of water. She overhears the wager and has the suit in the water before he asks the question.

That which was promised him. A tenant promises his daughter to his master against her will. The master sends for "that which was promised him." The daughter sends the horse, and it is taken into the master's chamber.
St. Peter not guiltless. Soldiers are admitted neither to hell nor to heaven. They remind Peter of his denial of Christ. He admits them.

God's omniscience. A woman tells her brother of God's omniscience. When he is ill and the priest has been called, he creeps under some straw and hides. The priest leaves. The man: "If God were so omniscient he might have found me for the priest."

The one word petition. A guardian of monks in need of food approaches the prince The prince is busy and says that he will permit the guardian but a single word. The guardian says, "Soup", and secures all the food he wants from the prince.
Wisdom acquired by hanging in a tree. Linked to Iceland

Sharing his wounds. Two men on parting agree to share everything they receive. One returns with much money. His friend reminds him of the pact. He replies that he has also received many wounds. The friend is willing to forego dividing.

The blacksmith's and the horse-trader's dreams. They are forced to sleep together because of lack of room. The blacksmith tells the horsetrader that he often dreams that he is striking the bellows and that he may accidently strike him in the night. The horsetrader retaliates by dreaming that he is riding a horse and drives the spurs into the blacksmith.
Drunkard cured of seeing double. When he claims to see two roast chickens, his wife takes the one chicken away and he falls into the fire trying to find the other.

The priest makes the omen come true. A woman crosses herself when she meets a priest, as if he were the devil. She says that meeting a priest always brings her bad luck. The priest knocks her down and steps on her. "As ye believe, so shall it be."

Armies like seeds and peppercorns. One king sends large sack of seed to the other to represent the number of his soldiers. The second replies with a small bag of peppercorns: "My army is small compared to yours but has all the power of the peppercorn compared to your lifeless seed."
The sound of the harp. An apprentice harpmaker is blamed that he has not made the harp sound. He throws the harp at his master's head and breaks it to pieces: "There you have your sound."

To give the accounting afterward. A nobleman embezzles money from the public treasury. When counsellors urge an accounting, he replies that he is ready as soon as they have themselves made an accounting of all their transactions. They are ready to let well enough alone.

Taking cold in effigy. A traitor is hanged in effigy naked. Later the citizens sue for peace and arrange a meeting. They find him in a hot room swathed with many blankets. He says that he has taken cold when the night wind blew on him as he hung naked from the gallows.
Wisdom purchased.
Man buys a pennyworth of wit. Found in England, From the region of West Indies
Man to bring wife a purseful of sense.
Fool is told to get a pottle of brains. He tries to buy them. He finally learns that advice was to marry a clever girl. Found in England
One eye exchanged for wisdom. (Odin.) Linked to Iceland
Good counsels bought. In languages spoken in Spanish, Linked to Indonesia, Linked to India, Linked to Spanish Exempla
An expensive joke. A shoemaker's apprentice greases boots as he would grease a fowl. The owner in anger returns and breaks a window.

The minstrel repays the cobbler. The cobbler learns the minstrel's songs and sings them so that the minstrel loses his trade. He in turn sews the cobbler's leather into crazy shapes. He has done no worse than the cobbler, who marred his songs. When they sing together the people realize the contrast and patronize the minstrel. In languages spoken in Spanish

Brotherly love and patience both dead. A man failing to receive alms in a village, rings the bell for mass. He tells the sexton that he is ringing because of the death of brotherly love. The sexton rings another bell. It is for the death of the other man's patience.

To follow the king. In order to test a favorite, a king says that he is going to retire from the world and offers the regency to the favorite. On advice from his philosopher, the favorite says that he is going to accompany the king into retirement. In languages spoken in Spanish, Linked to Spanish Exempla
Robber gives priest double his penance and then takes his horse.
He has a family to support. Ruler to servant stealing his game: "If you wish any I'll send you some." Linked to Italy, Linked to United States

Sticking to the rules. Merchant at inn deprives monk of fowl. "It's against the rules of your order." Later the monk undertakes to help merchant across stream. In the middle of the stream he asks the merchant if he has any money. "Yes." The monk drops him in the water. "It's against the rules of our order to have any money on us." Linked to Italy
Wisdom from God. Referenced in Jewish religious texts
Priest asked to preach short sermon does so saying to congregation only that they are wicked. Linked to Spanish Exempla, In languages spoken in Spanish
Do not start here. Man asks directions to a certain place. Native attempts to give directions, then in disgust says, "If I wanted to go to   , I wouldn't start from here." Linked to United States
Tree of knowledge. Linked to Ireland, Referenced in Jewish religious texts

The abbot cannot find his needle. An undesirable abbot furnishes adequate grounds for his dismissal when he cannot find the needle that all monks are supposed to carry with them. If careless in little things he will be careless in great.

Deduction: the one-eyed camel. A she-camel has passed, blind in one eye; on the one side she carries wine and on the other vinegar; two men lead her, one a heathen and the other a Jew. Solution: She is recognized as a she-camel by the footprints; she is blind because she feeds on only one side of the road; the wine dropping down has soaked into the earth; the vinegar makes bubbles; the heathen is not so careful in his manners as is the Jew. Linked to Italy, Spanning multiple countries: Korea, Linked to India

Animal cries misunderstood.
Owl's hoot misunderstood by lost simpleton.
The old maid answers the owl's hoot, saying "Anybody, Lord!". or giving the name of the young man she wants. Linked to United States
Frog's cries misunderstood. Linked to United States
Turkey's gobble misunderstood by man lost in woods. Linked to United States
Rooster's crow interpreted.
Henpecked husband leaves home. Hears a rooster crow, saying: "Cocky kuko! It's the same everywhere!" He returns home. Linked to United States
Other sounds misunderstood.
Seeds rattling in pods thought to be insults. Numskull burns field. Linked to India
Rabbits think sound of waves is great danger to them. Linked to Spanish Exempla, In languages spoken in Spanish
Fermenting dough: "Woe to you . Linked to Russia, Linked to Lithuania
Hissing of fire thought to be noise of cooking muffins. Linked to India
Noises fire is making misunderstood. Hunchback springs into it to burn to his death. Linked to India
Snoring sounds misunderstood.
Numskull thief thinks snoring sleeper is asking for food. Linked to India
Cooking processes misunderstood. Linked to India
Mushrooms shrink in water. Fool kills his wife because he thinks that she has eaten part of them. Linked to Ila (Rhodesia), Associated with the tribe Africa (Ila), Linked to Africa (Rhodesia)
Numskull thinks boiling pot is threatening him: breaks pot. Linked to India
Boiling milk thought to be overflowing. Simpleton lets it run over.
Numskull thinks his prayers have stopped milk boiling over. Actually his wife has added cold water. Linked to India
Boiling pumpkin thought to be talking. Linked to India
Boiling pot on the floor thought to be self-cooking.
Fish dancing about in cooking pot appears to be many. Cook eats one; none left. Linked to India
Handful of black pepper taken into mouth instead of cooking it in food. Linked to India
Savory tea. The peasant entertains a priest at tea. Making it, puts in all the tea, six pounds of sugar, a piece of bacon, etc. Linked to Lithuania, Linked to Russia

Sheep's head has eaten dumplings. Small boy is at home to watch the dinner. Runs into church, calls out to his mother that the sheep's head has eaten all the dumplings (or butted them out of the pot). Linked to United States
All the beans cooked for one meal. They fill the room. Linked to United States
Stupid servant cooks all the rice for one meal. Linked to India
Numskull stays till he has finished. As he is making water he hears a brook flowing and mistakes what it is. He waits for a day and a half. Linked to United States

Did the calf eat the man?. A fool, liking the shoes on the feet of a man hanged on a gallows, cuts off the swollen feet in order to carry off the shoes. In the room in which he sleeps that night is a newborn calf. The next morning the man takes the shoes but leaves the feet. Peasants agree that the calf has eaten the man all but the feet. They burn the house to destroy the calf. Linked to Denmark, Linked to United States
Fool thinks gold is being destroyed when snails crawl over it. Linked to Iceland
Fool thinks belly is speaking to him; stabs himself. Other animals are shouting at him. Linked to Indonesia
Animal's action misunderstood.
Urination of bull thought to be bleeding. Linked to India
Physical phenomena misunderstood miscellaneous. Linked to United States
Fools think thorn bush doesn't sting at night.
Simpleton sleeping in cold room breaks window to let the cold out. Linked to United States
Fool wakes with sleeping mat over head and thinks it is still night. Located in Marquesas
Varieties of wisdom.
"Forty-nine gates of wisdom"  open to Moses (and Solomon). Referenced in Jewish religious texts
Seventy-two kinds of wisdom. Referenced in Jewish religious texts
Inappropriate action from misunderstanding.
Swimming (fishing) in the flax-field. Peasants go to visit the sea. They see a waving flax-field, and, thinking it is the sea, jump in to swim. Linked to India, Found in Brittany
Trying to swim in the mist. Mistaken for sea. Located in Tonga
Sweeping with a stick instead of a broom.
Misunderstanding of church customs or ceremonies causes inappropriate action.
Misunderstandings concerning images of Christ.

Christ accused of trying to fool the people. Fool sees the image of Christ elevated on Ascension Day to the beams of the church. He accuses Christ of having fooled the people into believing that he has gone to heaven.

Christ's image has broken his arm. A man refuses to have anything to do with the crucifix because once an image of Christ has fallen on him in church and broken his arm. Reminded that this image is not the same, he replies that it is the son of the other and is just as bad.

The Lord has departed. Maidservant on way to church on Palm Sunday meets priests leading ass on which Jesus rode. The maid runs home and tells her mistress that the Lord has mounted and has just gone away.
Numskull knocks the figure of Jesus from the ass.

Bishop struck for breaking the peace. At a wedding after a period of silent prayer the bishop begins an antiphony. The fools walks up and strikes the bishop: "You have made this shouting in the church."
Numskull thinks the extinguishing of lights at the church presages a fight. Draws his sword.
Move away from Moslem land so that Allah need not be feared. Linked to India
Fatal bread. Numskull refuses communion because his sister died shortly after eating the bread.
Other misunderstandings of the communion.
Turkish ambassador misunderstands Christian ceremonies. Makes ridiculous report to his king.
Christian laws are profitless, Turkish ambassador says. Good people do not need them; bad people do not reform as a result of them. In languages spoken in Spanish
The falcon not so good as represented. A nobleman praises his falcon. His fool, supposing they were praising the falcon as food, kills the bird, but is disappointed in the taste.

The king no priest's son. A pope in writing to a king says, "To our dear son Frederick." Upon hearing this the fool cries out, "That is a lie; he is no priest's son. I knew his father and mother and they were both honest people."

The obedient log. A fool sees a boat (with rowers) obedient to commands, "Right! Left!" etc. He asks what kind of wood the boat is made of. Later he gets a log of that wood and tries to make it obey commands. Linked to Indonesia
Numskull throws the dishes out. A landlord in anger throws a dish out the window. The numskull throws the rest out, thinking that the landlord wanted to eat outdoors.

Jumping into the river after their comrade. Through misunderstanding one of the men jumps into the river. He calls out; the others think that he wants them to follow, and all jump in and are drowned. Linked to Japan
Numskull thinks the bishop's snoring is his death rattle. He strikes at a fly on the bishop's nose because it seems to be killing the bishop.
Numskull shoots grasshopper which lighted on the shoulder of his friend and kills friend. Linked to India
Boy strikes at a fly on his sister's breast: it turns into nipple and girl thinks it due to brother's caress. Linked to India
One man strikes at partridge which has lighted on second man's head. Linked to India
Numskulls lose corpse and bury live person instead. Linked to India
Goat chewing cud angers fool, who thinks goat is mimicking him. Linked to India
Fool not recognizing coins lying on roadside leaves them. Linked to India
Man thinks own toe is snake's head and cuts it off. Found in North Carolina
Useless surgical operation from misunderstanding.
Numskull (female devil) thinks her pubic hair has been telling her lies and pulls it out together with the skin. Linked to India
Fool cannot answer as his mouth is full;  thought to have an abscess in cheeks, allows them to be cut open. Linked to India
Bird protruding from king's stomach cut out with swords: king killed. Linked to India
Child's stomach split open to cure him of wandering. Linked to India

Serfs congratulate their master. The delegate slips and falls, cursing: "The devil may take you!" The serfs outside think this was the congratulation, and all cry in chorus: "You and your family!" Linked to Romania, Linked to Lithuania
Numskull prepares brother's wedding (father's funeral). On the way home from town he destroys his purchases. Linked to Lithuania, In the historic region of Prussia, Linked to Russia
Inappropriate action from misunderstanding miscellaneous.
Fool believes realistic story. Inappropriate action.
Story told about a deer: fool starts chase. Linked to India
Jackdaw tries to swallow sparks from glowworm. Linked to India
Numskull strikes all matches in order to try them.
Nobody can move it. Foolish soldier at guard by cannon therefore quits.
Wisdom wins contest of wisdom and wealth. Linked to India
Minister's clever daughter-in-law uses wisdom to defeat Brahmin's wealth. Linked to India
Gift or sale to animal (or object).
Gift to animal or object.
Gifts to frogs.
Numskull throws money to frogs so that they can count it.
Numskull feeds his wheat to frogs. He has been sent to mill to have it ground. In languages spoken in Spanish
Numskull throws money to frogs to repay them. They have frightened his fleeing ass from the water.
Wool taken to pond for frogs and toads to weave. Linked to India
Gifts to birds. Numskulls hear birds calling and give them gifts. Linked to Indonesia
Gift to object.
Fool stops hole with money. Found in Brittany
Thankful numskull puts money in the anus of sheep which he supposes has helped him.
Goods sold to animals.
Numskull sells cow to bird. When he comes for his money the bird flies to a trash pile, where the fool finds a treasure.
Fool sells balls of thread to great lizard. Next day he finds a treasure there. Linked to India
Oil sold to iguana. Treasure found. Linked to India
Goods sold to object. In languages spoken in Spanish
Fool sells goods to a statue. He is told not to sell to talkative people. The statue is the only one he can find who is not talkative. Linked to Italy, In languages spoken in Spanish
Money from the broken statue. Fool sells goods to a statue and when it will not pay him knocks it to pieces. He finds a treasure inside. Linked to Italy
Food given to object.
Meat fed to cabbages. Linked to Indonesia
Wisdom lost by accepting bribes and gifts. Referenced in Jewish religious texts
Animal or object absurdly punished.

Thief punishes the escaped ox. An ox strays on the rascal's land but escapes from him. The next week he sees the ox yoked up and gives him a beating. The master is astonished. The rascal: "Let me alone; he knows well enough what he has done."
The ass deprived of his saddle. A man's coat is stolen when he leaves his ass for a moment. He takes the saddle off the ass and says that he will give it back if the ass will return the coat.
Cow punished for calf's misdeeds. Blamed for not teaching calf better.
Man beats calves because the bull has butted him over the fence. Found in England
Wolf punished for his father's misdeeds. Referenced in Jewish religious texts
Man flogs his shot. On a rainy day when shot will not go a man flogs the shot. It goes and he shoots a deer. Associated with the tribe Africa (Vai)
Sickle punished by drowning. In a land where the sickle is not known the new sickle cuts off the head of a man. It is drowned.
Sickle punished by being tied in top of a tree. The men hang themselves in the attempt. Linked to Cheremis
Man avenges self on animals by wholesale slaughter.
Man avenges brother's death by wholesale slaughter of wild pigs. Linked to India
Man punishes offending part of his body.
Man beats his foot for slipping. Linked to India
Absurd sympathy for animals or objects.
Filling cracks with butter. Numskull sees cracks in the ground and feels so sorry for them that he greases them with the butter he is taking home. Linked to France, From the region of Missouri French

Creaking limbs. Numskull hears limbs creaking in the wind. He is sorry for them and holds them apart. While he is caught between them his enemies take advantage of him. Linked to India, Linked to No. Am. Indian
Creaking wagon dies. When the wagon stops its creaking, fool decides it has died; he cremates it. Linked to India
Helping the cuckoo. A numskull climbs a tree to help a cuckoo so that he may call louder than the one in the neighboring forest. Meanwhile his horse is eaten by a wolf.
Animals or objects kept warm.
Fool makes shoes for animals as well as men, since he expects a cold winter.
Cloak given to a stone to keep it warm. Linked to Japan
Warming the stove with wool.
King orders houses built to keep howling jackals warm in winter. Rascal misappropriates funds. Linked to India
Relieving the beast of burden.
Rider takes the meal-sack on his shoulder to relieve the ass of his burden. Linked to United States, Linked to Italy
Man puts bag of meal on one side of saddle, balances it on the other side with a rock. Linked to United States
Objects ascribed human feelings.
Kernel tries to escape death. A fool eats nuts. A kernel slips from him. The fool: "Everything tries to escape from death."
Complaint of the porridge pot. The woman thinks the boiling pot is complaining. Linked to Russia
The homesick wave. Numskulls try to take home a wave of the sea in a bamboo rod. At home when it refuses to wave they say that it is homesick for its mother, the sea. Linked to Indonesia
Coin weeps. Numskull thinks money piece covered with perspiration after he has held it for awhile is weeping. Linked to India
Absurd sympathy for animals or objects miscellaneous.
Men drag carts on to roof to shade it from the sun. Found in England
Animals or objects treated as if human miscellaneous.
Animal or object expected to go alone.
Object sent to go by itself. From the region of Missouri French, Linked to Indonesia, Linked to France, In languages spoken in Spanish
Cheeses thrown down to find their way home.
One cheese sent after another. Numskull lets one roll down hill; sends the other to bring it back.
Three-legged pot sent to walk home. Found in England, From the region of Missouri French, Linked to India, Linked to France, Linked to No. Am. Indian, In languages spoken in Spanish
Table thrown out of the sledge; to go home by itself.
Spinning wheel is sent home by itself. The man asks his wife if it has arrived before him, finds that it has not. "I thought not. I came a shorter way." Found in Scotland
Sickle laid in field and told to cut grain. Linked to India
Fool sends letter home by a flooded river. Linked to India
Animal sent to go by itself.
Ass loaded and commanded to go home. In languages spoken in Spanish
Fools send money by rabbit. Since he is a swift runner they expect it to reach the landlord in time. In languages spoken in Spanish, Linked to Spanish Exempla
Fishes to stop at his house. Fool directs them as he places them in stream. Linked to India
Foolish attempt to educate animals. Linked to India
Teaching chickens to talk. Fool believes they can be taught.
The ass as mayor. Fool made to believe that his ass (ox) has been educated and has become mayor. Found in England, Linked to India
Elephant educated as drum beater. Linked to India
Trickster joins bulrushes in a dance. He thinks they are dancing when he sees them waving. Linked to India, Linked to No. Am. Indian
Simpleton addresses a field of reeds. Linked to Italy
The boat gets tired. The woman tries to tire out her rival's boat so as to win the race, but only tires herself.
Singing snails rebuked. A boy roasts snails and they make noise in cooking. "Wretches, your house burns and yet you sing!"
Hens in mourning. Fool puts black clothes on his hen's necks. He tells people that they mourn their mother.
The mad wheelbarrow. Fools chain a wheelbarrow, bitten by a mad dog, lest it bite others.
Wants the organ to come and play for her. An old woman enraptured with the sound of a cathedral organ prays for it to come to her house and gives it directions as to where she lives.
Object foolishly blamed.

Sickness ascribed to quarreling wines. A man has drunk so much of various wines that he is sick. He says to the wines, "Have peace among yourselves and don't quarrel or I'll throw you out the window."
Carpenter blames the nails. On his deathbed refuses to forgive nails which ruined his tools.
Sea foolishly accused of cruelty. Sea says that it is calm itself, but the wind blew it up and broke the ship.
Preserving the cock's freedom. A boy recently home from school sees his mother trying to catch the cock. "Don't mother, don't break his freedom or we will suffer for it."
Scholar speaks Latin on hunt so that the birds cannot understand him. Linked to Italy
Woman thinks calf's bleating has accused her of stealing from harvest. Begs that people not believe what calf said. Linked to India
Objects supposed to be born, grow, and die like animals.
Stones thought to reproduce. Found in Hawaii
Acquisition and possession of wisdom miscellaneous. Linked to Iceland
Absurd disregard or ignorance of animal's nature or habits.
Absurd ignorance concerning the laying of eggs.
The overfed hen. A woman wants her hen to lay many eggs. Overfeeds her and she stops laying altogether.
Numskull feeds hens hot water so they will lay boiled eggs. Found in England
Absurd ignorance concerning the hatching of eggs.
Numskull sits on eggs to finish the hatching. Cautions people to be quiet and not frighten the eggs. Found in Brittany, Linked to Italy, In languages spoken in Spanish
Numskull tries to hatch out a calf from a cheese.
Absurd ignorance concerning animal's eating and drinking.
The water on the calf's back. When the calf will not drink, the peasant woman throws the water on its back.
Numskull puts the milk back. When the customer refuses to take the milk he puts it back into the goat's mouth so that it will flow back into the udder.
Fattening the pig. A farmer who wanted to fatten a pig fed it only twice a day. When told to feed it three times a day he says, "A working man must have more to eat than a pig."
How can an elephant eat, having tails at both ends?. Decision: it lives on air. Linked to India
Absurd ignorance concerning place for animal to be kept.
Cow (hog) taken to roof to graze. Linked to Switzerland, In languages spoken in Spanish, Found in England
The pent cuckoo. Fools build an enclosure to keep in the cuckoo. She flies over the hedge. They say that they have not built the hedge high enough. Found in England
Fools try to hedge the cuckoo so that they will have summer the year round (the coming of the first cuckoo being the sign of the coming summer). Found in England
Deer belled and enclosed like goats jump fence and escape. Linked to India
Hogs made to sleep in trees to cure their filthy habits. All are killed. Found in England
Nest built in tree for fish. Linked to India
Fish will climb trees like buffaloes. Numskull considers what will happen if river burns up. Linked to India
Absurd ignorance about milking animals.
Fool does not milk cow for a month so that she will give plenty for a feast.
Fools try to milk male ass.
Divided ownership of cow. The brother who owns the front end tries to drive the cow and will not let the owner of the rear end milk her. Linked to India
Fool asks owner of oxen why he does not milk them since he is not working them. Linked to Canada
Trying to have cows make curds before being milked. Linked to India
Cow killed in order to get all the milk at once. Linked to India
Absurd ignorance about slaughtering animals.
Bullock struck on hindquarters instead of head in attempt to kill it. (Only frightens it.) Linked to India
Absurd attempt to change animal nature.
The cat and the candle. A man has a cat trained to hold up lighted candles on its head. The king has a mouse let loose. The cat drops the candle and chases the mouse. Linked to India
Cat transformed to maiden runs after mouse.
Frog-woman betrays self by croaking. Associated with the tribe Africa (Nama)
Absurd disregard of animal's nature or habits miscellaneous.
Fisherman fails to make fish dance to his flute. Later in his net they jump about without the aid of the flute.
Fool tries to shoot dead antelope until it will come to him. Associated with the tribe Africa (Ekoi)
Numskull tries to shake birds from tree like fruit.
Breeding fine horses from an ass. Fool says, "Just as soon as the body of a colt bred from this mare is in proper proportion to its ears you will have a fine horse."
Sheep licking her lamb is envied by the wolf. He says, "Such is bad conduct. If I were to do that they would say that I was eating it." In languages spoken in Spanish
Numskull tries to wash black hen white.
Fear that frog may drown or get dirty. Linked to India
Wise men. Referenced in Jewish religious texts
Solomon as wise man. Referenced in Jewish religious texts
Other biblical heroes as wise men. Referenced in Jewish religious texts
Fatal disregard of anatomy.
Nature of a baby misunderstood.
Numskull does not understand about baby's skull. Sticks needle through it. In languages spoken in Spanish, From the region of West Indies
Foolish mother does not understand how babies cry. Wrings the child's neck. Linked to Ila (Rhodesia), Associated with the tribe Africa (Ila), Linked to Africa (Rhodesia)
Horse taught to live without food. Dies.
The underfed warhorse. Fails in the war.
Three brothers take turns using mule. None of them feeds him, supposing that the others have. The mule dies.
Fool carries wife across stream head downwards and drowns her. Linked to India
Fatal disregard of anatomy miscellaneous.
The remodelled stork. A trickster cuts off the bill and legs of a stork to make him look more like a real bird.

Where the ducks ford. A fool is asked where the river is fordable. He says, "Everywhere." The man tries to ride across and is almost drowned. The fool, "Those little ducks were able to cross here; why couldn't a big fellow like you?"
The two extra pounds. A dog has eaten 14 pounds of butter; the fool squeezes 16 pounds from him.
Fool cuts off tails of oxen so that they will look like fine steeds.
Genitals cut off through ignorance.
Ignorant bride castrates groom when jokingly told to do so. Linked to Italy
Nun tells friar to get rid of offending member. He does so. Linked to Italy
Fool undergoes castration to put on weight. Linked to Italy
Simpleton's ignorance of anatomy leads him to share his wife with a priest. Linked to Italy
Fool believes that he has begot child with his sister by an earbox. Linked to Iceland
The man without a member: foolish wife gives her husband money to buy himself one. Linked to Lithuania, Linked to Estonia
Cowboy shoots his wife when she breaks her leg (or is injured in another way). Linked to United States
Wise nations. Referenced in Jewish religious texts
Wisdom from "Children of the East." Referenced in Jewish religious texts
Wisdom from Egypt. Referenced in Jewish religious texts
Wisdom from the Greeks. Referenced in Jewish religious texts
Wisdom from the Hebrews. Referenced in Jewish religious texts
Absurd searches for the lost.
The needle (or the like) falls into the sea: sought the next summer.
Marking the place.
Marking the place on the boat. An object falls into the sea from a boat. Numskulls mark the place on the boat-rail to indicate where it fell. Linked to Japan

Marking the place under the cloud. Numskulls leave a knife in the field, marking the place by putting it under a heavy cloud. Next day the cloud is gone and the knife lost. Linked to Japan, Found in England
Fool seeks the ears of grain in the direction of the cloud toward which he has sowed them.
Marking the place in the sand. Vessel left under mound in sand while owner is swimming. Others make similar mounds so that it is lost. Linked to India
The rejected bread resought. Numskull looks for bread that he threw away a year before. Associated with the tribe Africa (Zulu)
Numskull forgets name of certain food and thinks that it has fallen into sand. Linked to India
Absurd disregard of natural laws.
Money tested by throwing it into a stream to see if it will swim. Good coins are supposed to swim, counterfeit to sink. Linked to Russia

Numskulls sow cooked grain. Linked to Japan, Linked to India
Sowing cheese to bring forth a cow.
Sowing salt to produce salt. Linked to India
Planting a hog in order to grow pigs.
Planting animal's tail in order to produce young animals.
Planting bones to produce animal. Linked to India
Sowing needles (like seed).
Harvesting early for half a crop. Linked to India
Stones watered to make them grow. Found in Hawaii
Numskull tries to dig up a well (spring). He wants to take it home.
A hole to throw the earth in. Numskull plans to dig a hole so as to have a place to throw the earth from his excavation. Referenced in Jewish religious texts

Boots sent by telegraph. A peasant hangs boots and an accompanying letter on a telegraph wire, expecting them to reach the city. From the region of U.S. (Ozarks)
How he looks in his sleep. A man stands before mirror with his eyes shut to see how he looks in his sleep.
Man takes mirror to bed to see whether he sleeps with his mouth open. Found in England
Absurd ideas about the dead.
Dead man identified by his cough. Numskull asked to identify corpse tries to do so by his cough.
A healthy place for a tomb. Numskull objects to unhealthy place for his tomb.
Porridge in the ice hole. They put meal in the boiling current of the ice hole and then, one after another, they jump in to taste the porridge. Linked to India, Linked to Indonesia
How far his voice will reach. A numskull cries from a tower and then runs away to see how far his voice will reach.
Holding in the heat. A numskull ties yarn around the stove to keep the heat from escaping.
Examining the sundial by candle-light. Numskull tries to find the time of night. Found in England
Sundial covered in order to protect it.
Trying to get fruit from fruitless tree.
Numskulls try to get pears from an oaktree. They accuse each other of eating all the pears.
Warming hands across the river. Numskull stretches out his hands toward the fire across the river.
As tired as if he had walked. So says the numskull after riding to town on his stick horse.
Drying snow to make salt.
Fire and water mixed to make sacrifice. Fool told that he needed only the two.
Demand that murderer restore life to victim.
Woman runs after guest to tell him he must restore her husband whom he has unintentionally killed. Linked to India
Absurd disregard of natural laws miscellaneous.
Simpleton drives goats into a well, because he thinks it would be cooler for them. Linked to India
Hot sickle put into water to cure its fever. Linked to India
Substitute for the corpse. Fool loses his mother's corpse on way to funeral. Mistakes old woman for mother and substitutes her. Linked to India
Other absurd disregard of facts.
White sheep-skin used as a source of light.
Trying to catch light in a mouse-trap.
The yeast as an afterthought. An old woman who has forgotten to knead it in the dough throws it into the stove.
The fool puts but one stick of wood in the stove. "Several others have burned up."
Tree-trunks laid crosswise of the sledge.
Trying to stretch the beam.
Protected by the needle. In a storm on the ice, numskulls stick needles into the ice to keep from blowing away.
The wall accuses the crowbar. But the man who uses the crowbar is to blame for the downfall of the wall.

Numskull bales out the stream. He comes to a stream but not wishing to get his feet wet he sits down to wait for the stream to run down. He helps to bale the stream out with a hazelnut shell and keeps it up for months. Linked to Italy
Foolish fight with the sea. Absurd attempt to punish sea. Linked to Indonesia
Foolish fight with the sun. Linked to India
Fools try to use buffalo tongue as a knife. Linked to Indonesia
Stupid woman swims on the roof. Linked to Switzerland
Tree pulled down in order to give it water to drink.
Fool tries to purify cotton by burning it (as the goldsmith does with gold). Linked to India
Numskulls are affected by heat from stove which has no fire in it. Linked to United States
Mouth and ears stopped up lest wisdom escape. Linked to India
Choices.
Hobson's choice: choose what is put before you or nothing.
Choice between eggs: one egg or none.
Uncertainty about own identity.
Person does not know himself.
Numskull's beard cut off: does not know himself. Linked to India
Woman's garments cut off: does not know herself.
Woman in tar and feathers does not know herself. Linked to India
Fool in new clothes does not know himself.
Man does not know himself from another identically clad.
Fool at baths believes he is someone else. Linked to Italy
Man made to believe that he is someone else. Linked to Italy
White man made to believe that he is a negro. Sleeps with a negro. His friends blacken him during the night. When he is waked up, he complains that they have waked the wrong man.
Man made to believe that he is a dog. He barks at people.

Pumpkin tied to another's leg. A numskull ties a pumpkin to his leg at night so that he shall know himself in the morning. Someone ties the pumpkin to another's leg and the numskull is not sure of his identity next morning.
Numskull made to believe he is an evil spirit. Linked to India
Fool does not recognize his own house and family. Linked to India
His pupils grab a dog's tail and think it is their master's. Linked to India
Man does not recognize his name when it is called: he is accustomed to hear his nickname. Linked to United States

Numskulls cannot find their own legs. A stranger helps them with a switch. (Usually get them mixed up when they sit down to bathe their feet.)
Numskull asks doctor which leg (own) is hurting him. Linked to Italy
Numskull cannot find ass he is sitting on.
Numskull doesn't recognize his own horse. Finds it only when the rest ride away and he takes the only one left. Linked to Italy
Numskull rides backward. "I didn't get on backward but the horse seems to be left-handed."
Inability to find object one is carrying.
Man searches for axe which he carries on his shoulder. Linked to Ila (Rhodesia), Linked to Africa (Rhodesia), Associated with the tribe Africa (Ila)
Woman cannot find pastry which is sticking to her posterior.
Fools try to fight with man inside of drum who seems to make the noise. Are really pounding each other. Linked to India
Opium-smoker on journey asks his way about; ends up at his own house. Linked to India
Absurd inability to count. Linked to India
Counting wrong by not counting oneself. Numskulls conclude that one of their number is drowned. Linked to Indonesia, Linked to India, Linked to Switzerland
Numskulls count selves by sticking their noses in the sand. They then count the holes.
There are ten horses; then when he is mounted there are only nine. Why? Linked to Italy
Culture hero throws coconuts to various islands, but forgets one he stands on: hence none now on that island. Linked to Cook Islands

Are there nine or ten geese?. Ten men are called in; each is to take a goose. If all have a goose, there are ten. One man is left without one. Numskull: "You should have taken one before they were all gone."
Three girls distressed by seemingly impossible task of going and returning together    one in half month, other in fifteen days, other in seven plus eight days. Linked to China

The interrupted calculation. While the merchant is making calculations, he asks the age of his youngest daughter, the elder daughter, and the mother, and always adds this to the number he has reached.
Keeping the measure by stretching out the arms. Numskull goes to buy goods for his wife.
Numskulls buy things in common: each pays full price.

Hang me right away so I can get back to work. Linked to India

Sham revenant. A man takes refuge from robbers in an open grave. Robbers see him and ask what he is doing. " It is my grave. I went out to get a breath of air.

" "For one thing, avoid mule-drivers.

Cold hands and feet for the dead man. His wife has told him that one tells a dead person by his cold hands and feet. He freezes his feet and hands and lies down for dead. Wolves eat his ass. " Lucky for you that his master is dead! Linked to India

Wife persuades husband that she has returned immediately. She goes to a neighbor's to cook a fish. She is gone a week. She gets a new fish and cooks it and returns home with the hot fish. She convinces her husband of her short absence.

The stag with iron shoes. Hunters shoot a stag and hide it. Another who sees puts a dead ass in the bag instead. When the bag is opened, one cries, "Oh Jesus, we have shot a stag with iron shoes!

She knows best: woman denies accusation of adultery. Husband dismisses the truthful accusers saying that she knows her shortcomings better than anyone else, and she denies it.

Fool kissed in sleep. Dreams he is being kissed by fairy. Is really a pig.

The woman who asked for news from home. Gets many impossible answers, which she believes. E.g., "The cock has become sexton. " "Yes, that is why he sang so well in the morning. " (First edition +X941.)
Animal betrays himself to his enemies by talking.

Fox holds conversation with his members, attracts attention, and is caught. He scolds in turn his feet, eyes, ears, and tail. In his excitement he sticks out his tail from his hiding place. In languages spoken in Spanish
Hidden wolf gives himself away by talking. Linked to Cape Verde Islands

Wolf (bear) boasts of having eaten horses. When the horse strikes sparks with his hoofs the lion is frightened and picks up the boastful wolf to show him the horse. He squeezes the wolf to death. In languages spoken in Spanish
Talkative man betrays his companion. When his faults are pointed out he maintains that he is better than his companion, who is immediately investigated.

His brother cannot pray either. One brother receives the sacrament; the other is refused it because he cannot pray. He replies that his brother cannot pray either and thus deprives him also of the sacrament.

The wife multiplies the secret. To prove that a woman cannot keep a secret the man tells his wife that a crow has flown out of his belly (or that he has laid an egg). Foolish boasts get man into trouble. Man boasts to boss that his brother can do twice the work he does. The boss hires him. " When they have robbed him he says, "Ask the merchant in the tree if my money is good. " They rob the merchant.

Scientific query: why does not the sea get larger when it rains in it and nothing flows out?

The judge wants to know how the theft was committed. The witness tells. The judge: "You are wonderful; I have tried it thirty times and succeeded only once.

The tailless and earless ass. Just lain down to sleep, a man is awakened by a neighbor announcing that his she-ass has borne a young one without ears or tail. The man lies awake all night wondering how the ass will keep the harness on.

How the first man killed himself. The second fool imitates the first who leaps from a palm tree by means of a looped rope. The first kills himself. The second wants to see just how it happened and kills himself too. Associated with the tribe Africa (Ekoi)

Curiosity satisfied: riding the ox's horns. As his ox, who has enormous horns, is asleep, the fool gets on the horns. The ox wakes and throws him off. When he comes to his senses, the fool says, "I had a hard time, but my curiosity is satisfied. Linked to India

Testing the evidence by experiment: biting the ear off. The accused pleads that the plaintiff bit his own ear off. The judge takes time for consideration, tries to bite his own ear, but falls down and breaks his head. Linked to United States

The philosophical watchman. A master sets his servant to keep watch over his horse at night. He soon asks the servant if he is asleep. " No, I was thinking of who created so many stars in the sky. " The second time the servant answers, "No, I was thinking of who dug the sea. Where did he put the soil? " The third time: "I was wondering who would carry the saddle now that the horse is stolen.
What will the robber do?. A man curious as to what a robber is going to do waits to intervene and goes back to sleep. Linked to India, Linked to Spanish Exempla, In languages spoken in Spanish
Question: did the man ever have a head?. A man's head is snatched off by accident and his companions do not see what has happened. Debate: did he ever have a head? Linked to India

Pity for the poor Jews. On Good Friday an old woman who has heard the Passion Story exclaims, "How hard it was for the Jews who had to watch all night with Christ!

Imitation of diagnosis by observation: ass's flesh. A doctor tells his patient that he has eaten too much chicken, and this the patient confesses. Healing with the cherry tree. A man whose wife refuses to talk remembers that a priest drank black cherry juice whenever he lost his voice. He cannot get the cordial but concluding that a limb of the cherry tree will have the same effect beats his wife with is. She is cured.

Ass tries to jump on the roof like the ape.

Animal dupe cuts off limb. Thinks he is imitating another animal.

Fowl makes another animal believe that he has had his leg cut off. Says that he has received large pay. He has his leg hidden under his wing. The elephant (hippopotamus) cuts his off and bleeds to death. Associated with the tribe Africa (Fang)
Fowl makes another animal believe that he has had his neck cut off. He has his neck hidden under his wing. The hare cuts his off and dies. Associated with the tribe Africa (Tsonga)

Useful wins contest over beautiful.
Contest between rose and amaranth: worth lies not in beauty.

Contest in beauty between swallows and crows (ants and flies): worth lies not in beauty.

The eye-juggler. A trickster sees a man throwing his eyes into the air and replacing them. He also receives this power but he must not use the power beyond a specified number of times. When he does so, he loses his eyes. He usually gets animal eyes as substitutes. Linked to India, Linked to No. Am. Indian

Numskull praises his daughter as being pregnant. He tries in vain to sell his cow and succeeds only when he says that she is with calf. When suitors come wooing his daughter, he tries the same plan disastrously.

Numskull puts money into the exchange so as to participate in the business. He hears that great lords take a part in the business of the exchange where he sees great heaps of money. He throws down a penny and says, "You may like it or not, but I want money in the exchange, too.
Usefulness better than speed.

A man undertakes to do his wife's work. All goes wrong.
Men exchange duties: each wants to get better of the other, but is cheated, finding the other's work more difficult. Linked to India
Man saved from well by rope. Disastrous attempt to save him from tree in same way. Linked to India

Father with handsome son and hideous daughter. Advises both to look in mirror daily lest son exchange handsome face for bad character; daughter to triumph over face by good manners.
Protecting as the stork does. Man has had stork protect him from rain by covering him with his wing. Man tries to protect his wife from rain with his arm. Linked to India
Useful and ugly preferred to expensive and beautiful.

King who experiences the cultural civilization of an empire in dream would rather be poor and primitive. Linked to India

Man criticizes the devil because his deeds are not fair. Devil says that they are strong nevertheless. Hence strong speakers rather than clever are to be preferred.
Hero, despising weapons, fights with fists alone. Linked to Ireland

Disastrous following of misunderstood instructions. (To burn land, then sow seed. Opposite done.) Linked to China

What should I have done (said)?. The mother teaches the boy (the man his wife) what he should say (do) in this or that circumstance. He uses the words in the most impossible cases and is always punished.
Literal following of instructions about actions.
Literal numskull drags jar (bacon) on string. He has sent a pig home alone. Told that he should have led it by a string. In languages spoken in Spanish

Literal fool strangles the hawk. On last trip he has lost the gloves and has been told that he should have put them in his bosom. He puts the hawk inside his shirt.

Numskull told to steal something heavy brings millstone. Linked to India
Numskull as thief: tries to carry off grinding-stone when told by confederates to bring out heavy things. Told to bring shiny things; brings out looking glass. Linked to India
Literal numskull destroys inherited property since his sister has instructions not to object to his actions. Associated with the tribe Africa (Hausa)
Literal following of instructions about greetings. Numskull gives wrong greeting and is told how to give the correct one. When he tries it, however, the conditions are wrong.
Literal numskull kisses a pig. Told that he should have kissed the old woman.
Fool learns to repeat commonplace expressions: by chance thus scares off wife's suitors. Linked to China
Literal numskull laughs at his child's death. Linked to India

Watering the cow (by pouring water on it). Linked to India
Collect goats under tree. "  Fool piles up their carcasses.
